name: diphenyl phosphoramidate
Reason: The basic unit here is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The diphenyl phosphoramidate molecule has two phenyl groups which can significantly increase the melting point due to pi-pi interactions and an increase in molecular weight. Each phenyl group may add approximately +100°C to the melting point. The phosphoramidate group introduces both P=O and P-N bonds, which can introduce additional dipole-dipole interactions and hydrogen bonding capabilities; this could add approximately another +30°C. However, these effects are not just additive because interactions within the molecule can affect the overall crystalline structure and hence the melting point. As a rough approximation, we would predict the sum of these effects to give us the final melting point.
Prediction: 235.5°C (5.5°C for the base benzene unit + 200°C for the two phenyl groups + 30°C for the phosphoramidate group)

name: diphenyl phosphoramidate
